Una, Himachal Pradesh

Una lies in southwestern Himachal, hugging Punjab. Much of the district is low-lying Swan (Soan) valley; hills begin toward Bangana and Chintpurni. It’s where the plains and hills meet, and that blend gives Una a unique flavour, Punjabi vibes in the food, Himachali soul in the hills.

Hidden Gems & Local Spots

  • Chintpurni Temple — Famous, yet a deeply local shrine. Families visit it on life events, and Navratri fairs turn it into a pilgrimage-festival.
  • Dera Baba Barbhag Singh (Mairi) — A lesser-known Sikh dera. During Hola Mohalla, devotion, healing, and festivity mix.
  • Piplu Ridge Viewpoint (Bangana) — Offers sweeping views of Gobind Sagar. A June fair brings together pilgrims and stall-vendors.
  • Shivbari Temple & Shiv Badi Forest — Near Gagret/Amb, quiet and sacred. Locals say the forest is under divine protection, no tree is cut.
  • Solah Singhi Fort Ruins — Hike 1 km up near Bangana to see old stone walls, a hidden tank, and broad views.
  • Unchha Pani — A simple picnic spot 15 km from Una, with streams and shade. Beloved by residents looking for a quiet day out.

Towns & Villages You’ll Pass Through

  • Una Town — The hub. Old fort Quila Baba Bedi, the main bazaar, War Memorial for 87 soldiers, and the College.
  • Gagret — Industrial + plain area. Shivbari Temple is nearby. Many factories and steel markets.
  • Amb — Close to the hills. Base town for Chintpurni pilgrims, has the railway terminus (Amb Andaura), a bustling morning grain market.
  • Bangana — The “hill side” of Una. Cooler climate, terrace farms, folk traditions stronger.
  • Haroli / Santokhgarh belt — Plains near Punjab. Mehatpur is the border town with truck stops, small industries. Also houses IIIT Una and a private university in Bathu.
  • Villages like Mairi, Basoli, Nari, Kuthar, Ajouli — Each has a story: shrines, old houses, ancestral customs, local fairs.

Culture & Celebrations

  • Harmony: Hindus, Sikhs, Muslims live in close proximity. Temples, gurudwaras, and dargahs often share space emotionally if not physically.
  • Navratri Fairs at Chintpurni: The biggest religious fair in district twice a year. Vendors, folk shows, spiritual energy.
  • Hola Mohalla (Baba Barbhag Singh): A weeklong Sikh fair with gatka, kirtans, spiritual healing.
  • Village fairs & harvest festivals: Sair, local deity melas, folk dancing, community feasts.
  • Dance & music: In hills — Pahari Nati; in plains — Bhangra & Gidda. Women sing Suhag, Ghorian at weddings. Instruments: shehnai, nagada, algoza.
  • Dress: Men in kurta-pajama or shirt-pant; elders or Sikh men wear turbans. Women in salwar-kameez; older women may wear ghagra. In Bangana, shawls appear in colder months.

Youth & Learning

  • Schools everywhere: Every village has a primary school; tehsil towns have senior secondaries.
  • Higher education: 8 degree colleges, Indus International University (Bathu), and IIIT Una (Saloh) offering modern tech education.
  • Vocational training: ITIs, polytechnic for trade skills.
  • Aspirations: Many youth aim for the armed forces, government jobs, or professional education. Sports (hockey, kabaddi) are alive. Youth clubs, school tournaments are common.
  • Migration: Many go to Chandigarh, Delhi, or Punjab for studies and jobs but often return with skills.

Our Stories

Exploring the majestic peaks of the Himalayas, capturing breathtaking moments.

Immersing ourselves in the rich culture and vibrant traditions of Himachal Pradesh.

Food & Markets

  • Meals: Wheat roti, daal, sabzi. In winter, sarson ka saag + makki roti is a favorite.
  • Special Dishes: Patrodu (leaf roll), Sepu Badi Madra (festival gravy) and dhaam.
  • Punjab Influence: Paranthas, dal makhani, tandoori rotis, chole-bhature, golgappa, and much more.
  • Local Produce: Arbi, potatoes, riverbed cucumbers/watermelons, mangoes, kinnow, local honey.

Travel & How to Get Around

  • By Road: Major routes: Nangal–Una–Hamirpur; Hoshiarpur–Gagret–Amb–Kangra. Buses from Delhi, Chandigarh, Amritsar, Dharamshala.
  • By Train: Broad-gauge line from Nangal → Una → Amb Andaura. Station is Una Himachal (UHL).
  • By Air: No airport. Nearest: Gaggal (Kangra) 100 km, Chandigarh 130 km.
  • Local Transport: Himachal buses, shared taxis, moto-bikes, auto-rickshaws in town.
  • Best Time:
    • Spring / Autumn: ideal (pleasant, festivals).
    • Summer: hot.
    • Monsoon: tricky for travel, roads can slip.
    • Winter: cool days, cold nights — good for quiet visits.
